seed.  The  rule  @(−,−,−,−)(1,0,0,0) ⇒ (−,0+,0)   converts  a  block  attached  to  its  first  face  so  that  another  sea block can be attached to the end of the chain. See the  description  of  the  rule  notation  on  the  project’s  web  site  or in [1].  We  conducted  experiments  with  the  “snake”  configuration  using  different  friction,  boundary,  and  moment  of  inertia  parameters  to  explore  the  range  of  possible behaviors.  In  most  cases  the  resulting  structure  is  a  single  long  chain of blocks. Even though the chain may break apart in  the middle, the pieces tend to eventually reattach restoring  a single long chain. In a high friction environment with a  spherical  or  cubic  boundary,  a  piece  of  the  chain  may  break away and form a loop (Figure 1).
Figure 1. Snake configuration. Broken piece
forms loop.

We  also  used  the  simula tion  environment  to  explore  behavior  of  meso-blocks  with  fixed  charges,  genetic-algorithm-generated  meso-block  systems  with  enzymes  [2],  and  dynamic  multi-agent  structures  such  as  a  meso-block motor.
4. C onclusion
The simulation system is a feature-rich tool for further  modeling  and  exploration  of  self-assembly  and  other  phenomena in multi-agent systems.

We expect that the simulation environment will help us  to  bridge  theoretical  work  in  the  area  of  multiagent-systems  with  practical  development  in  biology,  chemical  engineering, and nanotechnology.

The first experiments conducted with the system have  led to better understanding of self-assembly properties of  meso-blocks  and  their  dependence  on  the  physical  properties  of  the  environment.  The  current  meso-block  model  does  not  define  means  to  store  or  transfer  information  among  the  agents.  This  somewhat  limits  the  ability  to  assemble  predefined  shapes.  The  simulation  system helps us to specify and test new additional features  of the meso-block model to overcome such limitations.

The  simulation  environment  can  also  be  used  in  combination with genetic algorithms to develop enzymes  [2]  or  other  static  and  dynamic  structures  with  desired  properties.

We  expect  to  further  develop  the  system  to  simulate  other  physical  interaction  models,  such  as  molecular  interaction.  For  example,  we  would  like  to  assess  the  possibility  of  simplified  modeling  of  carbon  atom  interactions using the tetrahedral structures.
Our overarching goal is to advance the theory of selfassembly  in  multi-agent  systems  and  to  find  robust  physical implementation of self-assembly models.  5 . References
[1] Guo, Y., et al., Designing Self-Assembly for 2-Dimensional  Building  Blocks,  ESOA'03  Workshop  (during  AAMAS-03)  in  Melbourne, July 2003.

[ 2]  Poulton,  G.,  et  al.,  Designing  Enzymes  in  a  Multi-Agent  System  based  on  a  Genetic  Algorithm,  8th  Conference  on  Intelligent Autonomous Systems, Amsterdam, The Netherlands,  March 2004.
[ 3]  Goldberg,  D.E.  Genetic  algorithms  in  search,  optimisation,  and  machine  learning.  Addison-Wesley  Publishing  Company,  Inc., Reading, Massachusetts, 1989.
[ 4]  Wolfram,  S.  ed.,  Theory  and  Application  of  Cellular  Automata, World Scientific, Singapore, 1986.
[ 5] H. Haken, Synergetics. Springer-Verlag, Berlin, 1983.

[ 6] Garis H., Artificial Embryology: The Genetic Programming  of an Artificial Embryo, Chapter 14 in book "Dynamic, Genetic,  and Chaotic Programming", ed. Soucek B. and the IRIS Group,  W ILEY, 1992.
[7]  Whitesides,  G.,  et  al.,  Mesoscale  Self-Assembly  of  Hexagonal  Plates  Using  Lateral  Capillary  Forces:  Synthesis  Using the 'Capillary Bond', J. Am. Chem. Soc., 1999, 121, 5373- 5391.

[8]  Whitesides,  G.,  et  al.,  Three-Dimensional  Mesoscale  Self-Assembly, J. Am. Chem. Soc., 1998, 120, 8267-8268.   [ 9]  Whitesides,  G.,  et  al.,  Design  and  Self-Assembly  of  Open,  Regular, 3D Mesostructures, Science, 1999, 284, 948-951.   [10]  Raguse,  B.,  Self-assembly  of  Hydrogel  Mesoblocks,  personal communication, CSIRO, 2002.
[ 11]  Bojinov,  H.,  Casal,  A.,  Hogg,  T.:  Multiagent  Control  of  Self-reconfigurable Robots, Fourth International Conference on  MultiAgent Systems, Boston, Massachusetts, 2000.
